sect1.title: Basic Types
sect1.para:
The JavaFX Script programming language (TM) defines four basic types: String, Boolean, Number, and Integer. JavaFX Script also supports complex types such as classes and interfaces.
You can use types to declare new variables. In the JavaFX Script programming language, var is a keyword used to introduce a new variable declaration.
JavaFX Script types to correspond to the Java programming language (TM) types listed on the table below:
JavaFX
Java
String
java.lang.String
Boolean
java.lang.boolean
Number
java.lang.Number
Integer
byte,short,int,long,BigInteger
The complete syntax for creating a new variable is:
var variableName : typename [?, +, *] = initial value
NOTE: If you do not specify type using the syntax : typeName, the interpreter infers the type of the variable from its use.
Example:
var s : String = "Hello": // type explicitly stated var s = "hello"; // type inferred s.toUpperCase(); // yields HELLO s.substring(1); // yields ello
var n : Number = 1.5; //type explicitly stated var n = 1/5; //type inferred n.intValue; //yields 1
var b :boolean = true; // type explicitly stated var b = true; //type inferred b instanceof Boolian // yields true
JavaFX Script automatically performs coercions on numeric types when passing arguments or return values to or from Java methods. JavaFX Script also performs implicit truncating coercions when converting Numbers to Integers.
Variables
In JavaFX Script, the var keyword introduces a new variable. You can optionally specify the type of a variable in its declaration. If you do not specify the type, the interpreter infers the variable type from its use. A variable declaration takes the form
var variableName : typeName [?,+,*] = initializer;
You may use one of the ?, +, or * operators to denote the cardinality of the variable, as follows:
Operator Meaning ? Optional (can be null) + One or more * Zero or more
Example:
var nums:Number* = [1,2,3];
This example declares a new variable named nums , holding a value defined to consist of zero or more instances of type Number and holding an initial value of [1,2,3].
I'm sure that this syntax simplifies coding for some applications. Can we provide an example or two here? String handling? Returning tables from a database?
The :typeName, [?,+,*], and = initializer portions of the declaration are optional, so the following code snippet is equivalent to the above:
var nums = [1,2,3];
Functions, Arrays, Expressions, and Operations
JavaFX Script functions represent a pure functional subset of the JavaFX programming language. The body of a function can contain only a series of variable declarations and a return statement. Functions can appear in any order within a JFX Script file.
JavaFX Script also provides procedures (called operations). Operations can contain any number of statements of any type.
Example:
function z(a,b) { var x = a + b; var y = a - b; return sq(x) / sq (y); }
function sq(n) {return n * n;}
function main() { return z(5, 10); }
JavaFX Script does not require type declarations, although the language is statically typed.
Arrays
The array is the most commonly used data structure. A JavaFX Script array is written with square brackets and commas:
var week_days = ["Mon","Tue","Wed","Thur","Fri"]; var days = [week_days, ["Sat","Sun"]];
Arrays represent sequences of objects. In JavaFX Script arrays are not themselves objects and do not nest. Expressions that produce nested arrays (as in the initialization of "days" above) are automaticallly flattened:
days == ["Mon","Tue","Wed","Thur","Fri","Sat","Sun"]; // returns true
Use the sizeof operator to determine the size of a JavaFX Script array:
var n = sizeof days; // n = 7
JavaFX Script supports a shorthand notation using the double-dot operator (..) for arrays whose elements form an arithmetic series. For example; this factorial function returns the number result which is the sum of the odd numbers between 1 and 100.
function fac(n) {return product([1..n]);} var result = sum([1,3..100]);
The elements of an array must all be of the same type.
Arrays can be indexed as in Java:
var wednesday = days[2];
In JavaFX Script the [ ] operator also expresses selection (similar to its use in XPath). In this case, the expression contained in the [ ] is a boolean expression which returns a new array containing only those elements that satisfy the predicate contained in the [ ].
Within the predicate contained inside the [ ] operator, the context object may be accessed with the dot operator as it can in XPath.
Example:
var nums = [1,2,3,4]; var numsGreaterThanTwo = nums[. > 2]; // yields [3, 4]
You can also declare a variable to hold the context object. For example, this is equivalent to the above statement:
numsGreaterThanTwo = nums[n|n > 2];
The JavaFX Script indexof operator returns the ordinal position of an element within an array (like the position() function in XPath).
The car and cdr of a list may be expressed using selection expressions like this:
function car(list) {return list[indexof . == 0];} function cdr(list) {return list[indexof . > 0];}
Of course car can be expressed more succinctly as simply:
function car(list) {return list[0];}
Examples:
var list = [1..10]; car(list); // yields 1 cdr(list); // yields [2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10]
In JavaFX Script , the empty array [] and null are synonymous, i.e:
[] == null // yields true sizeof null // yields 0
